annotation:
Kirsten Marie appears to mock the widespread belief in ghostly apparitions in this story. Niels's amusing response--that a headless horse had stuck its head in through the window--at once confirms and undermines the belief. 

     Tang Kristensen made a slight change to the wording of the story, so that the reference to the headless horse came first. In this manner, the story became primarily a story about the headless horse, rather than a story about Niels Bødker's amusing response to the doubters. Kirsten Marie told another variant of the story in her second session with Tang Kristensen (KMP 2.14).
danish_manuscript:
I Nielstrup var en Mand der hed Niels Bødker.
De fortalte af, at der gik en hovedløs Hest
op og ned ad Gaden. [Dh.] Nogle s. at det var
ikke sandt. Men dh. Karl s. at det var sandt
for den Hest havde rækket

5215A
Hovedet ind ad Hakkelsehusvinduet, mens h.
stod og skar hakkelse.
english_manuscript: There was a man called Niels Bødker in Nielstrup. They said that there was a headless horse that went up and down the streets. Some people said that it wasn't true. But this guy said that it was true, because the horse had stuck its head in the window of his chaffing room while he stood there cutting chaff.
danish_publication: De fortalte af, at der gik en hovedløs hest op og ned ad gaden i Nielstrup. Nogle sagde, at det var ikke sandt, men Niels Bødker sagde, at det var sandt, for den hest havde rækket hovedet ind ad hakkelsevinduet, imens han stod og skar hakkelse. Han boede siden som mand i Nielstrup.
english_publication: They said that there was a headless horse that went up and down the streets in Nielstrup. Some people said that it wasn’t true, but Niels Bødker said that it was true, because the horse had stuck its head in the window of his chaffing room while he stood there cutting chaff. Later, when he was a grown man, he lived in Nielstrup.
